awd_titl_txt: Coarse Grained Modeling & Control of Colloidal Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the proposed project is to develop computational models of ensembles of differently shaped colloidal particles as a means to control their assembly into ordered microstructures with few defects. The proposed research may enable metamaterial applications involving micro-structured colloidal-based materials for manipulation of electromagnetic radiation. Example materials include novel reflectors, gratings, polarizers, waveguides, etc. as part of sensors, solar cells, antennas, optical computers, and cloaking devices, which all require periodic structures of different shaped particles with low defect densities. The focus of the research project will be on modeling and control of ellipsoidal and super-ellipsoidal particles to enable a rich set of microstructures. Novel methods for controlling interactions using directional and time varying inputs will be developed to enable precise control of colloidal particle assembly processes.

Understanding the thermodynamics and kinetics in colloidal systems is challenging and applying feedback control adds an additional layer to engineering complex responses in such systems.  The goal of the proposed research is to develop minimal physically-meaningful models of stochastic dynamics to design model-based feedback control policies for the assembly of ellipsoidal and super-ellipsoidal particles. The objective is to significantly adapt and extend prior approaches to systematically define coarse grained system coordinates that capture structural features while eliminating system symmetries. The feedback control policies will be tested experimentally with tunable kT-scale interactions to design dynamic reversible assembly of different shaped particles into ordered metamaterials. The fundamental understanding of design rules and control parameters for colloidal assembly will provide new general insights beyond what is known from trial-and-error discovery. The project will train students by integrating broad topics in colloid science, fluid dynamics, materials chemistry, advanced metrology/microfabrication, and control. Broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields will be pursued through weekly mentoring activities at a local elementary after-school program focused on engineering design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to employ an integrated suite of experimental, computational, and theoretical methods to control assembly of different shaped colloidal particles on surfaces to enable a rich set of microstructures. Creating micro-structured colloidal-based materials on surfaces can produce metasurface properties for manipulation of electromagnetic radiation in novel reflectors, gratings, polarizers, waveguides, etc. as part of sensors, solar cells, antennas, optical computers, and cloaking devices, etc. The project developed models of colloidal assembly dynamics to design feedback control policies to remove defects and guide assemblies towards ordered liquid crystalline and crystalline states in minimal time. Findings demonstrated how particle shape and interactions could be designed to yield a variety of technologically useful surface microstructures. In addition, methods were developed to control dynamic assembly processes to achieve such target microstructures.

The intellectual merit of the research was based on fundamental insights into colloidal assembly processes through the development of new modeling tools, extending such tools to increasingly complex particle shapes, and guiding the design of real world experimental systems. The broader impacts associated with this project included the discovery, development, and optimization of tools to enable advanced material manufacturing as well as training undergraduate and graduate students through participation in the project.

Outcomes of this research, disseminated in presentations and journal articles, include a better understanding of how external electric field mediate colloidal interactions together with dynamic models can be used to control assembly of different shaped particles into non-trivial surface microstructures. Findings include: (1) understanding how particle shape determines possible microstructures in two-dimensional particulate systems to enable design of particle based surface materials, (2) controlling interfacial assembly and reconfiguration of different shaped particles between microstructures of varying order including amorphous, liquid crystalline, and crystalline states, and (3) demonstrating the spatially controlled assembly of hierarchical microstructures on electrode arrays.
